I am aware that many people who call themselves conservative seem feel that one of the parts of being "conservative" involves keeping the government out of the lives of individuals, but political science coins the term differently. According to political science, there are sort of four corners of political ideology. These are conservative, libertarian, liberal, and populist.
 
 Conservatives believe in government intervention in the moral and social realms, but not in the economic realm.
 
 Libertarians believe in no government intervention in neither the social and moral realm nor the economic realm.
 
 Liberals believe in no government intervention in social and moral realm, but government intervention in the economic realm.
 
 Populists (aka Authoritarians) believe in government intervention in both the social and moral realm as well as the economic realm.
 
 This fun little quiz can tell you where you stand! http://www.ontheissues.org/quizeng/XPolitics/start.asp (Just click the Don't Save button at the bottom if you want to take the quiz without registering).
 
 I'm not sure how good it is, but I come up as a liberal-libertarian (I'm on the line between liberal and libertarian) which accurately describes me, as I support keeping the government out of social and moral issues, while I am moderate when it comes to government intervention in the economy.
 
 I will not argue that modern Republicans seem to be acting more like populists/authoritarians than usual, sometimes tending toward increasing government intervention in both fiscal issues and social/moral issues.
